Fig. 1 (a) the conversion of p-CNB using Au catalysts prepared by NaBH4 reduction, Au sol adsorption, and DP method; (b) the conversion of p-CNB and the selectivity of p-CAN using Au catalysts with different Au loading by Au sol adsorption method (Reaction conditions: 100 ℃, 1.2 MPa H2, 2 h; 0.787 g p-CNB, 25 mL CH3OH). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a and b) the TEM images of 0.5 %Au/NC obtained via gold sol adsorption and (c) the corresponding Au size distribution, (d) the TEM image of 0.5 %Au/NC(DP), (e) the TEM images of 0.5 %Au/NC(NaBH4) and (f) the corresponding Au size distribution. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The catalytic performance of (a) x%Pd-0.5 %Au/NC and (b) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/xNPC in the catalytic reduction of p-CNB (Reaction conditions: 100 ℃, 1.2 MPa H2, 0.787 g p-CNB, 25 mL CH3OH; Reaction time: (a) 2 h, (b) 1 h). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The catalytic performance of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC (Reaction Conditions: 0.787 g p-CNB, 25 mL CH3OH, 1 h; (a) at 100 °C with varying H2 pressures, and (b) at 1.2 MPa H2 and varying reaction temperatures). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 the TEM images and the corresponding metal size distribution (a and b) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC, (c and d) 0.5 %Au/NPC, and (e and f) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) XRD patterns of NPC, 0.5 %Au/NC, 0.5 %Au/NPC, and 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC; (b) Raman spectra of NC, NPC, and 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Au 4 f XPS of (a) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC and (b) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC; Pd 3d XPS spectra of (c) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC and (d) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 P 2p XPS spectra of NPC, (b) 0.5 %Au/NPC and (c) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Arrhenius plots of p-CNB reduction over (a) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC and (b) 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC. Libo Sun contributed equally to this work. In this paper, an efficient catalyst (0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC) was prepared by supporting Pd-Au bimetallic nanoparticles on a phytic acid-doped polyaniline-derived N/P co-doped carbon (NPC) support. The catalytic performance of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC for the p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) hydrogenation to p-chloroaniline (p-CAN) was systematically evaluated. Experiments demonstrated that the introduction of trace amounts of Pd significantly enhanced the conversion rate of the Au-based catalyst while maintaining good selectivity. The NPC support optimized the dispersion and surface electronic states of the metal nanoparticles by enhancing the metal-support electronic interaction, enabling the catalyst to achieve complete p-CNB conversion with a good selectivity (>98 %) under conditions of 100 °C and 1.2 MPa H2. The P doping induced an electron-deficient state on the metal surface, promoting preferential adsorption of -NO2 groups in p-CNB and desorption of -NH2 of products p-CAN, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. This paper provides a new strategy for developing efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts for the hydrogenation of halonitroaromatics and offers a novel method for regulating the electronic structure of noble metals in carbon-based noble metal catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Pd-Au bimetallic catalyst N and P co-doped carbon Hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene Selective hydrogenation Electronic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chloroaniline is an important chemical intermediate with extensive application value in various fields, including pharmaceuticals, dyes, pesticides, and others [1–3]. Generally speaking, its preparation entails the reduction of chloronitrobenzenes, with iron powder, sulfiding alkalis, or hydrazine hydrate frequently utilized in industrial settings. Nonetheless, as environmental protection standards progressively escalate, these reduction processes confront a myriad of challenges, encompassing elevated production costs, suboptimal reaction efficiency, and potential environmental pollution issues [4]. Using a metal catalyst for the catalytic hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzenes with H2 is an efficient and environmentally friendly preparation method [5–7]. The hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene encounters not only selective competition for benzene ring saturation but also selective dechlorination due to the presence of halogen [8,9]. In the liquid-phase catalytic hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes, a series of heterogeneous catalysts based on noble metals, including Pd [10], Ru [11], and Pt [12], has demonstrated remarkable catalytic performance, attributed to the significant enhancement of the hydrogenation process efficiency. However, their ability to selectively produce chloroaniline as the key target product often falls short of ideal expectations. Since Hutchings and Haruta achieved groundbreaking accomplishments in the field of gold-containing catalysts [13,14], nano Au catalysts have garnered extensive research interest and attention due to their exceptional selectivity and low-temperature activity advantages. In recent years, Au catalysts have showcased their immense potential across numerous industrial and scientific domains, encompassing a range of vital chemical processes such as CO oxidation, acetylene hydrochlorination, propylene epoxidation, oxidative esterification of alcohols or aldehydes, glucose oxidation, nitro compounds hydrogenation, and acetylene semi-hydrogenation, among others [15–19]. The nano-Au catalyst has demonstrated exciting results in the field of selective hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes, particularly notable for its exceptional selectivity in precisely catalyzing the formation of halogenated anilines. B. Yang and his collaborators had discovered that despite a relatively low conversion rate (less than 25 %), the Au/CeO2 catalyst exhibited remarkably high selectivity (reaching 100 %) in catalyzing the p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) hydrogenation into p-chloroaniline (p-CAN) [20]. Y.-W. Chen and Y.-T. Tsu successfully loaded Au onto various supports using the deposition-precipitation method and reached similar conclusions. Specifically, regardless of whether CeO2, TiO2, ZrO2, ZnO, or Fe2O3 was used as the support, these Au-loaded catalysts all demonstrated extremely high p-CAN selectivity, with values exceeding 98 %. However, in terms of p-CNB conversion rates, with the exception of the Au/TiO2 catalyst, which performed relatively well, the conversion rates of the other catalysts were less than ideal, ranging from 25.4 % to 77.8 % [21]. The high selectivity of Au catalyst in the preparation of p-CAN from p-CNB hydrogenation had also been confirmed by C. H. Campos and his collaborators [22]. Enhancing the conversion rate of Au in catalyzing the p-CNB hydrogenation has thus emerged as a central challenge and a crucial step towards achieving their widespread applications. Given the outstanding hydrogenation properties exhibited by metals such as Pt, Pd, and Ru, several research teams have actively explored the integration of these elements into gold-based catalyst systems, aiming to significantly enhance the catalytic efficiency and performance of the catalysts through this innovative strategy. B.-Q. Xu and coworkers found that adding a minute amount of Pt (ranging between 0.01 % and 0.03 % by weight) onto the Au/TiO2 catalyst represents a potent strategy to boost the efficacy of Au in the p-CNB hydrogenation, all while preserving its exceptional selectivity towards the production of p-CAN [23]. Additionally, our recent research endeavors have revealed that incorporating an ultra-low concentration of Pd leads to a remarkable catalytic enhancement for Pd-Au/TiO2, as compared to its Au/TiO2 counterpart [5]. For the mesoporous silica-supported AuPd bimetallic alloy catalyst, the main catalytic product in the hydrogenation reaction of p-CNB is aniline (AN), which is obtained through dechlorination and hydrogenation [24]. Therefore, the selection of catalyst support becomes particularly crucial. Y. Wan reported a type of Au-intercalated ordered mesoporous carbon catalyst, where the Au nanoparticles (NPs) are reduced through carbonization of the carbon-rich matrix, enabling the efficient selective hydrogenation of aromatic nitro compounds [25]. Recently, carbon-based materials have surfaced as significant catalyst support due to their abundant pore channels and readily tunable surface properties [26,27]. Heteroatoms, including N, P, S, and B, can anchor and disperse metal particles while simultaneously modulating their electronic states [28]. The synergistic effect of heteroatom doping and the regulation of metal active sites can collectively enhance catalytic reaction activity [29]. Inspired by this, we are deeply curious and eager to explore the specific performance of the carbon-based supported Pd-Au bimetallic catalyst in the catalytic hydrogenation reaction of p-CNB. According to our extensive review, there is a lack of detailed reports in relevant literature in this field so far. Despite the excellent selectivity exhibited by gold catalysts in the p-CNB hydrogenation, their low conversion rates limit the practical applications. Current research lacks in-depth exploration of the synergistic effects of bimetallics and the regulatory mechanisms of heteroatom co-doped carbon supports. In this study, we aim to construct a bimetallic catalyst that possesses both high activity and selectivity by combining the excellent H2 dissociation capability of Pd with the high selectivity of Au, and leveraging the anchoring and electronic regulation effects of N and P co-doped carbon supports on metal nanoparticles. This study fills the gap in the field of conductive polymer-derived carbon-based bimetallic catalysts toward to the halogenated nitrobenzenes hydrogenation and provides theoretical support and technical reference for the green synthesis of chloroanilines. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, analytical grade), sourced from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute. During the experiment, H2 and N2 were purchased from Yantai Feiyuan Special Gas Co., Ltd. Other reagents, such as HAuCl4, H2PdCl4, phytic acid (C6H18O24P6, PA), p-CNB, ammonium persulfate (APS), and aniline, were from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., without any further treatment prior to use. The water utilized in the experiment was deionized. 2.2 Preparation of Au sol and Pd-Au bimetallic sol The gold sol was prepared by referring to our previous work [30]. In short, a combination of 1.33 mL HAuCl4 solution (concentration: 9.56 mgAu/mL), 431.25 g water, and 1 mL of 2 wt% PVA solution was thoroughly mixed and magnetically stirred at 200 rpm under ice-cold conditions for 20 min. Following this, NaBH4 (2.5 mL, 0.1 M) was cautiously introduced drop by drop to the mixture, which was further agitated for 2 h. Eventually, a Au sol (vibrant wine-red) containing gold NPs (29.16 mgAu/L) was successfully synthesized. The bimetallic Pd-Au sol was prepared by modifying the method described in the literature with the specific steps outlined below [31]. Firstly, 40 mL of the Au sol prepared according to the aforementioned method was taken, and 3.6 mL ascorbic acid (AA, 0.1 M) solution was introduced. After stirring for 5 min, 0.115 mL of H2PdCl4 solution (1 mgPd/mL) was introduced and stirred at 200 rpm for 12 h. At this point, a bright brown Pd-Au bimetallic sol containing Pd-Au bimetallic NPs (Au: 26.68 mgAu/L, Pd: 2.63 mgPd/L) was obtained and stored at 4 ˚C in the refrigerator. 2.3 Preparation of nitrogen doped carbon support (NC) and nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped carbon support (NPC) and their supported Pd-Au bimetallic catalyst The preparation of the NC support is achieved through the pyrolysis of polyaniline (PANI) under a N2 atmosphere. The PANI is prepared by modifying the method according to the literature [32], briefly summarized as follows: 50 mmol of aniline was stirred with 40 mL H2O, and the pH was regulated to 0.4 by HCl acid. Then, a pre-cooled APS solution (2.5 M, 20 mL) was introduced. The mixture underwent vigorous stirring at 500 rpm for 1 h, followed by a 24 h period at room temperature where it was allowed to stand undisturbed. Ultimately, the product underwent washing by water and ethanol, followed by drying at 60 ˚C for 12 h. The obtained PANI was subjected to pyrolysis in an N2 atmosphere for 1 h at 800 ˚C. The heating process was steady with a temperature rise of 5 ˚C/min with a N2 flow (40 mL/min). The obtained black powdered solid was denoted as NC. The preparation of the NPC support is achieved through the pyrolysis of PA doped PANI (PA-PANI) under a N2 atmosphere.Varying volumes (2.4, 4.8, and 9.6 mL) of PA (70 wt%, 1.6 g/mL) were introduced into 100 mL of H2O and allowed to fully dissolve, followed by the addition of 1.5 mL of aniline. Separately, 1.8 g of APS was mixed with 10 mL H2O and was then carefully dripped to the aniline mixture while stirring at 500 rpm thoroughly. The combined solution was stirred at 0–4 ˚C for half a day, leading to a dark green mixture. The obtained mixture was subsequently washed by water and ethanol, and the resulting dark green powder was dried for half a day at 60 ˚C. The product was designated as xPA-PANI, where x signifies the molar ratio of PA to aniline. During the preparation, the use of 1.2, 2.4, 4.8, and 9.6 mL of PA corresponds to the production of 0.125PA-PANI, 0.25PA-PANI, 0.5PA-PANI, and 1.0PA-PANI, respectively. PA-PANI was pyrolyzed in an N2 atmosphere for 1 h at 800 ˚C. After naturally cooling, a black powdered solid NPC was obtained. When the ratio of PA to aniline in the NPC precursor PA-PANI needs to be precisely defined, xNPC is used. The preparation process for 0.5 %Au/NC was as follows. Firstly, 0.1 g of the support NC was uniformly suspended throughout 2.5 mL H2O. Next, 17 mL of prepared Au sol was slowly introduced, and continuously stirred at 500 rpm for half an hour. Subsequently, the suspension was purified to remove unbound Au sol and other contaminants. Ultimately, the sample, after being washed by water, was dried for 12 h at 60 ˚C, and 0.5 %Au/NC was obtained. Using the same preparation process, we had also successfully synthesized 0.5 %Au/NPC using NPC as the support. The preparation procedures for the bimetallic catalysts, 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC and 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC, were largely identical to the aforementioned steps, with the sole difference being the substitution of the previously used Au sol with pre-prepared Pd-Au bimetallic sol (18.75 mL). 2.4 Characterization Full methodological details for all tests and analyses can be found in the Supporting Information. 2.5 Catalyst test The catalytic activity of the prepared catalyst was evaluated through the hydrogenation of p-CNB to produce p-CAN. The reaction took place in a 80 mL stainless steel reactor. Initially, 50 mg of catalyst and reaction solution (0.7875 g of p-CAN in 25 mL of CH3OH) were sequentially introduced to the reactor. Subsequently, the reactor was purged with H2 three times. The sealed reactor was placed in a thermostatically controlled magnetically stirrable heater and heated to the predetermined reaction temperature. H2 was then charged to the target pressure, and the agitation speed was regulated to 500 r/min. At this point, the reaction began and the timing was started. Upon completion of the reaction, gas chromatography (GC) was then utilized to analyze the products of the p-CNB hydrogenation reaction, and the composition and content of the solution were confirmed by the internal standard method. For the GC analysis, a capillary column (HP-5) was chosen, and the detector was a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). The subsequent formulas were adopted to calculate the p-CNB conversion, the p-CAN selectivity, and the Turnover Frequency (TOF) of the reaction. (1) Conversion ( % ) = 1 − C p − CNB C p − CNB + C p − CAN + C AN (2) Selectivity ( % ) = C p − CAN C p − CAN + C AN (3) TOF = Conversion p − CNB ( % ) × W p − CNB × M Au M p − CNB × W catalyst × Loading ( % ) × time wherein, Cp-CNB, Cp-CAN, and CAN refer to the concentrations of p-CNB, p-CAN, and AN respectively. Wp-CNB and Wcatalyst represent the masses of reaction substrate and the catalyst. Mp-CNB and MAu denote the molecular masses of reaction substrate and gold respectively. 3 Results and discussion In this work, trace amounts of Pd are incorporated into a carbon-based nano Au catalyst, and its performance in the p-CNB hydrogenation to p-CAN is investigated. As depicted in Scheme 1, initially, PA-PANI is synthesized through polymerization, using PA as the dopant and APS as the oxidant. PA is doped into the PANI molecular chain through a large number of electrostatic interactions and intramolecular hydrogen bonds (Ⅰ) [33,34], thereby introducing P element into PANI. Subsequently, the PA-PANI is pyrolyzed under a N2 atmosphere to obtain the NPC support. Pd-Au bimetallic NPs is prepared by introduce small amount of H2PdCl4 into the freshly prepared Au sol with AA as the reducing agent (Ⅱ). Finally, the Pd-Au NPs in Pd-Au sol were adsorbed on the NPC surface to form the Pd-Au bimetallic catalyst. For comparative experimentation, we also employed NC support without PA doping to support the active metal NPs, and conducted thorough analysis and comparison on them. For the p-CNB hydrogenation to produce p-CAN, Au-based catalysts generally exhibit excellent selectivity [20,21]. However, factors such as the preparation method of the catalyst and the loading amount of Au significantly affect the catalyst’s activity [35]. To address this, in addition to the 0.5 %Au/NC prepared by the gold sol adsorption, we also prepared, for comparison, catalysts 0.5 %Au/NC(NaBH4) and 0.5 %Au/NC(DP) using NaBH4 reduction method, and urea deposition-precipitation (DP) method, respectively. The preparation methods of them are detailed in the Supporting Information. Their activities are presented in Fig. 1. It is particularly noteworthy that all three Au catalysts exhibit 100 % selectivity, a finding that fully validates the exceptional selective performance of Au catalysts. In terms of conversion efficiencies, catalysts 0.5 %Au/NC(NaBH4), 0.5 %Au/NC, and 0.5 %Au/NC(DP) yield values of 3.7 %, 11.4 %, and 8.0 %, respectively, with 0.5 %Au/NC demonstrating the highest conversion efficiency, indicating the better catalytic performance of Au catalysts prepared by Au sol adsorption method. The morphology of the catalysts prepared by different methods and the size distribution of Au NPs are shown in Fig. 2. In Figs. 2a and 2b, the gold particles exhibit a spherical shape and are evenly spread on the support surface, of a size of 4.1 ± 0.7 nm, which is consistent with the gold NPs size in Au sol (Fig. S1, 4.1 ± 0.6 nm). This suggests that the NC support has the ability to stabilize the Au particles effectively. The 0.5 %Au/NC obtained via the gold sol adsorption exhibits smaller sizes and better dispersion of gold. For 0.5 %Au/NC(DP), only a small number of Au particles with sizes in the tens of nanometers were observed in its TEM (Fig. 2d). And for 0.5 %Au/NC(NaBH4), although a large number of Au particles were observed (Fig. 2e), their sizes (5.6 ± 1.4 nm, Fig. 2 f) were relatively larger compared to those in 0.5Au%/NC. Additionally, we tested the Au content in the filtrate after the reaction or adsorption process and found that all the active gold was loaded onto the support, which is attributed to the excellent property of the NC support to anchor and disperse metal particles [28]. Therefore, the 0.5Au%/NC catalyst prepared by Au sol adsorption exhibited well-distributed gold particles with stable and small sizes, resulting in the good activity. Fig. 1b displays the catalytic performance of catalysts with varying Au load content prepared by the Au sol adsorption method. Within 2 h, all catalysts exhibited 100 % selectivity for p-CAN. The conversion rates of p-CNB for the 0.3 %Au/NC, 0.5 %Au/NC, 1 %Au/NC, 1.2 %Au/NC, and 1.5 %Au/NC were 2.9, 11.4, 7.2 %, 1.4 %, and 1.1 % respectively. As the loading increases, the catalytic activity first rises and then decreases. When the loading exceeds 0.5 %, the catalytic activity diminishes. We tested the morphology and size distribution of 1.5 %Au/NC and found that the Au NPs had grown in size (4.3 ± 0.7 nm, Fig. S2), leading to the decrease in catalytic activity. Considering atomic economy and catalytic performance, a theoretical Au loading of 0.5 % is deemed the most reasonable. Therefore, in the subsequent experiments, the catalyst was prepared using the sol adsorption, and the theoretical loading of nano Au was controlled at 0.5 %. Although the catalyst obtained via the Au sol adsorption demonstrates superiority compared to the DP method and the NaBH₄ reduction method, its conversion rate still falls short of expectations. This is attributed to the relatively weak H2 dissociation ability of nano Au [36]. As is well-known, Pd catalysts are renowned for their exceptional hydrogenation activity [37]. In light of this, we attempted to incorporate a trace amount of the second metal, Pd, into the Au catalyst. We adjusted the Pd loading in the Au-based catalyst by varying the amount of H2PdCl4 solution used during the preparation of the aforementioned Pd-Au bimetallic sol. As shown in Fig. 3a, the addition of trace amounts of Pd significantly enhances the catalytic activity of 0.5 %Au/NC. As the content of Pd rises, the p-CNB conversion rate steadily increases. Specifically, when the Pd loading attains 0.05 %, complete conversion of p-CNB can be achieved in just 2 h, while exhibiting a high selectivity of 99 % towards p-CAN. However, further augmentation of the Pd content results in a sharp decrease in p-CAN selectivity due to the excessive dissociation ability of Pd towards H2 [38]. For comparison, the 0.05 %Pd/NC catalyst prepared by the same method (see Supporting Information) showed only 1.3 % conversion of p-CNB under identical reaction conditions, demonstrating negligible catalytic activity, which clearly indicates that the introduction of trace Pd (0.05 %) alone produces almost no catalytic effect while a distinct synergistic catalytic effect exists in the Pd-Au bimetallic system. Therefore, to balance the demands of high conversion efficiency and high selectivity, we have selected a theoretical optimal Pd loading of 0.05 % for catalyst preparation. Unless otherwise specified, this ratio of Pd-Au bimetallic composition will be adopted subsequently. As is well-known, the heteroatoms in carbon-based supports affect the stabilization and dispersion of metal particles, and this influence typically encompasses the metal size, electronic properties, and the metal-support interaction (MSI), thereby further affecting the catalytic behavior of the catalyst [39]. Fig. 3b shows the catalytic performance of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/xNPC catalysts with different PA introduced during the NPC preparation. It is noteworthy that the catalytic activity of the Au-Pd bimetallic catalyst supported on NPC has been significantly enhanced compared to that supported on NC. Under the same reaction conditions, the catalytic reaction time is shortened by nearly half, demonstrating the significant advantage of P doping. Among them, the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/0.5NPC catalyst exhibits the best activity, achieving a conversion rate of 100 % and a selectivity of 98.1 % after reacting for 1 h at 100 °C under 1.2 MPa of H2. Therefore, in subsequent experiments, unless otherwise specified, the support NPC used will be 0.5NPC. It should be noted that neither the pure NC nor NPC support exhibited any activity for the hydrogenation of p-CNB. The reference catalyst 0.05 %Pd/NPC prepared by the identical method (see Supporting Information for detailed preparation procedure) exhibited nearly no conversion of p-CNB (1.8 %) under the same evaluation conditions, further confirming the synergistic effect between Au and Pd in the bimetallic system. Fig. 4 depicts the activity of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC under various reaction temperature and pressure conditions. At 100 °C and 0.8 MPa, the conversion rate is 78.6 %. As the pressure increases, the overall conversion rate exhibits an upward trend, reaching 100 % at a pressure of 1.2 MPa, with a selectivity of 98.6 %. Changes in pressure have a noticeable impact on the conversion rate, but the selectivity remains almost unchanged, indicating that pressure does not induce side reactions. The effect of temperature on the reaction follows a similar trend, with the conversion rate gradually increasing as the temperature rises until complete conversion is achieved. At 100 °C and 1.2 MPa, full p-CNB conversion is achieved, and the selectivity is close to 100 %. Overall, within the tested pressure and temperature range, the catalyst almost exclusively catalyzes the p-CNB to p-CAN, demonstrating its excellent selectivity. Therefore, the optimal reaction conditions should be controlled at 1.2 MPa and 100 °C, under which the catalyst 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC exhibits the best performance. After six months of sealed storage, the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC maintained excellent catalytic performance, demonstrating complete conversion of p-CNB and high selectivity toward p-CAN (97.5 %). These results convincingly demonstrate its outstanding storage stability and indicate promising potential for industrial applications. As shown in Fig. S3, the Pd-Au bimetallic sol exhibited a spherical shape with a particle size of approximately 3.8 ± 0.7 nm. Compared to the Au size distribution in gold sol (4.1 ± 0.6 nm), the size of bimetallic particles decreases. This phenomenon suggests that the subsequently added metal Pd does not continue to grow on the surface of Au particles to form a core-shell structure, but rather exists predominantly as individual Pd particles within the bimetallic sol. Moreover, the small Pd particles physically isolate the Au NPs, resulting in the decrease of Au size. Due to the relatively low content of Pd, its particle size is also smaller, leading to an overall reduction in the statistically averaged particle size. After loading, regardless of whether NC or NPC is used as the support (as shown in Figs. 5a and 5e), the metal particles can be uniformly dispersed on the support while maintaining their spherical structure. Additionally, benefiting from the exceptional adsorption properties of the carbon-based support, the size of the bimetallic particles is reduced, averaging at 3.5 ± 0.7 nm, which fully demonstrates the carbon-based support’s outstanding ability to stabilize and disperse nanometal particles. Notably, there is no obvious change in particle size regardless of the introduction of phosphorus. In Fig. 5c, the Au size distribution on NPC after adsorbing Au sol is similar to that of 0.5 %Au/NC. Therefore, it can be inferred that Pd in the catalyst prepared from bimetallic colloids mainly exists in the bimetallic system as Pd metal. The introduction of trace amounts of Pd reduces the particle size of Au. The introduction of phosphorus does not alter the average size of the active metal. Fig. S4 shows the HAADF-STEM photo and elemental distributions of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. On the NPC support, besides N, P, and O, Au and Pd elements are also present, and the regions where Au and Pd exist do not coincide completely. Lattice fringes of Au (111) (0.234 nm) [40] and Pd (111) (0.231 nm) [41] can also be observed separately in Fig. S5, further confirming the existence of the Pd-Au catalyst in the form of Au and Pd particles. In the XRD spectra of Fig. 6a, it is observed that both the support and the catalyst exhibit a obvious diffraction peak at 2θ = 24° of the (002) plane of carbon, confirming that both materials possess an amorphous structure. The peak at 2θ = 44° belongs to the (100) plane of carbon, indicating that the material has been successfully carbonized [42]. Compared to NPC, the characteristic peaks at 2θ = 38.1° for both 0.5 %Au/NC and 0.5 %Au/NPC are attributed to the (111) plane of Au, indicating successful loading of Au NPs onto the supports [43]. However, for the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC catalyst, no peaks corresponding to Au and Pd are observed, indicating that the introduction of Pd has reduced the average size of Au, which is consistent with the analysis results obtained from the TEM images. After measuring the metal content in the filtrate after adsorption using ICP, it was found that both the NC support and the NPC support achieved complete adsorption of both Au sol and Pd-Au bimetallic sol, implying that NC or NPC support possess excellent stability towards noble metal particles. Raman spectra analysis can provide supplementary evidence. As shown in Fig. 6b, all samples exhibit two broad bands at approximately 1340 and 1580 cm−1, belonging to the D (disordered carbon) and G (crystalline graphitic carbon) band of the material [44]. The value of ID/IG represents the degree of graphitization, and a ratio greater than 1.00 indicates a higher degree of defects [45]. The ID/IG values in the Raman spectra of all materials are greater than 1, indicating the presence of numerous defect sites in the materials. These formed defects facilitate the adsorption and anchoring of metal NPs. As shown in Fig. S6a of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, all four samples exhibit type IV characteristics, indicating their mesoporous structure. The textural parameters of supports and catalysts are shown in Table 1. Compared to NC, NPC exhibits a larger surface area, pore size and volume. This is attributed to the role of PA in the doping of PANI, where it not only acts as a dopant but also as a cross-linking agent, facilitating cross-linking between PANI molecular chains and altering the stacking of polyaniline molecular chains. Additionally, the escape of phosphorus-containing gases generated during the pyrolysis process, along with the incorporation of phosphorus into the carbon framework, induces defects or micropores. These multiple factors collectively influence the specific surface area and pore structure after pyrolysis. After loading with noble metal particles, the surface areas of both catalysts decreased due to the adsorption of noble metals onto the support. Notably, the catalyst supported on NPC exhibited a more significant reduction in pore size and volume in comparison to the catalyst supported on NC, despite using the same batch of adsorbed colloidal particles. Therefore, it can be inferred that there is a stronger interaction and more effective contact between NPC and the bimetallic colloids, leading to the reduction in pore volume and pore size. Fig. 7 presents the Au 4 f and Pd 3d XPS spectra of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC and 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. In Fig. 7a, for 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC, the binding energies (BE) at 83.98 and 87.65 eV correspond to the 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2 splitting levels of Au0 [46]. When the support is NPC, the BE of Au 4 f7/2 for 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC shifts to a higher value of 84.20 eV. This indicates a stronger electronic interaction between gold and the support after the introduction of P, with electrons flowing from Au to the support, resulting in an electron-deficient surface of metalic gold (Auδ+, 0 < δ < 1) [47]. For both NPC and NC supports, when the active component is solely Au, comparing the XPS of 0.5 %Au/NC and 0.5 %Au/NPC yields the same result (Fig. S7). Specifically, the presence of P facilitates a robust electronic interaction between the active metal and the carrier. Electrons flow from the Au particles to the support, resulting in an electron-deficient surface of the Au NPs. In Fig. 7c, two distinct peaks are observed for 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC at approximately 340.62 and 335.13 eV, which are the Pd0 3d3/2 and Pd0 3d5/2 energy levels [48]. The process of deconvolving these peaks reveals the presence of oxidized palladium (Pd2+) at a BE of 337.22 eV [49], suggesting a lack of electrons on the Pd0 surface and indicating the existence of electronic interactions between Pd and the support. The ratio of Pd2+/Pd0 was determined by inspecting the BE of the Pd 3d core levels, with the calculation based on the relative peak areas corresponding to Pd2+ and Pd0. For 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC, the ratio of Pd2+/Pd0 was found to be 4.56 %. However, for 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC, this ratio increased to 12.49 %, indicating an enhanced interaction between the support and the metal particles after P incorporation. Consequently, the Pd surface becomes more electron-deficient and positively charged. In Fig. 8a, the P 2p spectrum of NPC can be decomposed to peaks P-C at 132.62 and P-O at 133.50 eV [50]. The formation of P-C indicates that P elements are incorporated in the carbon skeleton during the carbonization process. We observed that when Au NPs are anchored on the NPC, the binding energy of P-C undergoes a slight shift to 132.46 eV. Furthermore, upon the introduction of Pd, the binding energy of P-C continues to shift to 132.38 eV, representing a lower BE value, indicating that the electron transfer from metals to support. This confirms that there are electronic interactions among Au, Pd, and P, leading to changes in the electron density around P-C and noble metals, leading to an electron deficiency on Au and Pd particles’ surface. It is well-known that Pd exhibits excellent dissociative ability for H2, enabling efficient hydrogenation reactions with only a small amount of Pd. However, its selectivity is relatively poor. The Pd2+ can effectively moderate the hydrogenation activity of Pd NPs, thereby preventing over-hydrogenation from occurring [5]. Due to the strong electron-withdrawing nature of the -NO2 group relative to the benzene ring, the benzene ring in nitroaromatics is in an electron-deficient state. Under hydrogenation reaction conditions, p-CNB molecules tend to adsorb via coordination between the nitro group and the metal catalyst, as the nitro group is more favorable for adsorption than the benzene ring. That is, electron-deficient metal NPs can enhance the adsorption of nitro groups [51,52]. Furthermore, the amino group in the resulting product has a weaker electron-withdrawing effect, making it easier to desorb from the catalytic surface, thereby improving the catalytic selectivity. Table S1 presents the adsorption of the two catalysts towards the reaction substrate p-CNB and the product p-CAN without H2 added. The data in the table clearly show that, compared to the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC, the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC exhibits stronger adsorption capacity for p-CNB, while its adsorption capacity for p-CAN is relatively weaker. This result further supports that electron-deficient metal particles can effectively promote the adsorption of reactants and the desorption of products. The apparent activation energies (Ea) of the catalysts 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC and 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NC in the reduction of p-CNB, as calculated using the Arrhenius equation, is 21.27 and 23.80 kJ/mol ( Fig. 9). The detailed testing procedures are provided in the Supporting Information. This result once again confirms the high efficiency of the 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Regardless of whether NPC or NC is used as the support for preparing the catalyst, we employed the same batch of bimetallic colloids, meaning that the size and distribution of the metal particles are essentially the same. The interaction between the NPC support and the Au and Pd metals modulates the surface electronic state of the metals, rendering their surfaces electron-deficient and enhancing their catalytic behavior. Table 2 presents a comparison of the performance of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC with that of catalysts reported in the literature. Although the reaction conditions of Pd5.0/O-C550 [9] were relatively mild, its TOF (4641 h−1) was lower than that of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC (7086 h−1), and the selectivity to p-CAN was also not satisfactory (∼70 %). Compared with the Au/CeO2 catalyst [20], the introduction of a trace amount of Pd in 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC significantly reduced the reaction conditions and the Ea of the reaction. The catalytic performance of the Pd-Co@SiO2 [53] catalyst remains inferior to that of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC even under higher hydrogen pressures. The reaction conditions for PtNi/TiO2 [54] and Pd@Graphene quantum dots-porous carbon sphere [55] are relatively mild, but their TOFs are also significantly lower than that of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. The performance of the Ru catalyst supported on a carbon-based support [56] is also weaker than that of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Therefore, through the above literature comparison, the superiority of the NPC catalyst is once again confirmed. Scheme 2 proposes the possible reaction mechanism for the catalytic p-CNB hydrogenation over 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC. Firstly, the doping of P results in electron deficiency on the surfaces of Au and Pd, which facilitates the preferential adsorption of the -NO2 in p-CNB onto the metal surface [52,57]. H2 dissociates on the surface of Pd to form hydrogen active species (H*) and undergoes hydrogen spillover to the Au surface. Subsequently, the adsorbed p-CNB on the metal surface undergoes hydrogenation with H* to obtain the product p-CAN [58]. Finally, the product desorbs from the catalyst surface, and the active metal sites are released again. When the sizes of Au and Pd particles are consistent, the contribution of electronic effects to catalytic activity becomes more prominent. The introduction of P onto the NC support through PA doping results in electron deficiency on the surfaces of Au and Pd. This promotes the adsorption of the -NO2 group in the starting material p-CNB and the desorption of -NH2 group in the p-CAN product, significantly enhancing both catalytic activity and selectivity. To explore the reusability of the catalyst, we controlled the reaction time at 0.5 h, at which point the initial activity resulted in an 81.7 % conversion of p-CNB ( Fig. 10). After five cycles of use, the conversion rate decreased to 51.5 %, representing a reduction of approximately 30 % with a catalytic selectivity > 99 %. We collected and combined the reaction solutions after each catalytic cycle, and analyzed the metal leaching by ICP. Results showed that the leaching amounts of Au and Pd were extremely low and nearly undetectable. The actual loadings of Au and Pd in the cycled 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC were measured to be 0.49 % and 0.048 %, respectively. TEM image in Figure S8 demonstrates that the metallic nanoparticles on the surface of the cycled catalyst maintained good spherical morphology, but their average particle size increased from 3.5 ± 0.7 nm for the fresh catalyst to 4.3 ± 0.1 nm. The sintering of active-phase particles is identified as the key factor responsible for the decrease in catalytic activity. Future work should focus on further improving the anti-sintering performance while maintaining the excellent initial activity of the catalyst to enhance its cycling stability. 4 Conclusions In this paper, a highly efficient and stable Pd-Au/NPC catalyst was designed and prepared through a bimetallic synergy and heteroatom doping strategy, and the enhanced mechanisms in the hydrogenation of p-CNB were systematically elucidated. The key conclusions are as follows: (1) The introduction of trace amounts of Pd (0.05 wt%) boosted the conversion rate to 100 % by enhancing H₂ dissociation capability, while maintaining high selectivity through electronic effects; (2) P doping in the NPC support induced electron-deficient states on the metal surface, promoting -NO2 adsorption and product desorption; (3) The catalyst achieved a TOF of 7086 h⁻¹ and a Ea of 21.27 kJ/mol under mild conditions (100 °C, 1.2 MPa H2), outperforming similar reports in the literature. This work provides a new strategy for the efficient conversion of halonitroaromatics, and future research should further explore approaches to enhance the cycling stability of the catalyst and to scale up its preparation. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, an efficient catalyst (0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC) was prepared by supporting Pd-Au bimetallic nanoparticles on a phytic acid-doped polyaniline-derived N/P co-doped carbon (NPC) support. The catalytic performance of 0.05 %Pd-0.5 %Au/NPC for the p-chloronitrobenzene (p-CNB) hydrogenation to p-chloroaniline (p-CAN) was systematically evaluated. Experiments demonstrated that the introduction of trace amounts of Pd significantly enhanced the conversion rate of the Au-based catalyst while maintaining good selectivity. The NPC support optimized the dispersion and surface electronic states of the metal nanoparticles by enhancing the metal-support electronic interaction, enabling the catalyst to achieve complete p-CNB conversion with a good selectivity (>98 %) under conditions of 100 °C and 1.2 MPa H2. The P doping induced an electron-deficient state on the metal surface, promoting preferential adsorption of -NO2 groups in p-CNB and desorption of -NH2 of products p-CAN, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. This paper provides a new strategy for developing efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts for the hydrogenation of halonitroaromatics and offers a novel method for regulating the electronic structure of noble metals in carbon-based noble metal catalysts.
